page.title: Botany of Piper methysticum
page.subtitle: A deep dive into the taxonomy, morphology, and ecology of the Kava plant.

intro.paragraph1: Piper methysticum, commonly known as Kava or Kava-Kava, is a tropical shrub from the pepper family (Piperaceae). The name Piper methysticum translates to "intoxicating pepper" (from the Greek methystikos = intoxicating).
intro.paragraph2: Unlike many other psychoactive plants, Kava does not contain alkaloids as its main active compounds, but rather a unique class of substances known as Kavalactones. The plant has played a central role in Pacific Island cultures for thousands of years and is the result of millennia of human selection.

classification.title: Scientific Classification
classification.note: The closest related species is Piper wichmannii, which is considered the wild ancestor of today's cultivated Kava plant. While P. wichmannii (often called "Wild Kava") can reproduce sexually, cultivated P. methysticum is sterile and completely dependent on humans.

morphology.title: Morphological Overview
morphology.intro: Kava is a perennial, evergreen shrub that typically reaches a height of 1.5 to 3 meters, but can grow up to 5 meters under optimal conditions.

belowGround.title: Below-Ground Parts
belowGround.roots: Lateral Roots (Waka): Finer roots, highest kavalactone content

distribution.title: Distribution & Habitat
distribution.intro: Kava is native to the western Pacific. The origin is believed to be in northern Vanuatu, where the greatest genetic diversity exists. From there, the plant was spread across the entire Pacific by Polynesian seafarers ("Canoe Plants").
distribution.regionsIntro: Today, Kava is mainly cultivated in the following regions:

regions.vanuatu: Vanuatu: The world's largest producer with over 80 different varieties.
regions.tonga: Tonga: Produces very mild, "creamy" Kavas (e.g., Pouni Ono).
regions.hawaii: Hawaii: Kava is called 'Awa here (e.g., Moi, Mahakea).
regions.pohnpei: Pohnpei & Micronesia: Known for consuming fresh Kava juice ("Sakau").
